case_name: Sri Mahant Kaushalya Das v. State

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 131 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 251 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JUIUSDICTION Civil Appeal No. 131 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 29, 1963 -of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 251 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant Sri Mahant Kaushalya Das was convicted under s. 4(1)(a) of the Madras Prohibition Act.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the Madras High Court dated April 29, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 251 of 1963 affirming the companyviction of the appellant-Sri Mahant Kaushalya Das under s. 4  1   a  of the Madras Prohibition Act

facts.text: The sentence imposed was one year Rigorous Imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 50 or in default rigorous imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: affirming the companyviction of the appellant-Sri Mahant Kaushalya Das under s. 4  1   a  of the Madras Prohibition Act and the sentence of one year Rigorous Imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 50 or in default rigorous im- prisonment for one month.

facts.text: The appellant is the hereditary Mahant of Sri Bairaghi Matam, a Hindu Religious and Charitable Institution of a monastic nature.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the hereditary Mahant of Sri Bairaghi Matam -a Hindu Religious and Charitable Institution of a monastic nature.

facts.text: The appellant has been residing in the Matam premises, Elephant Gate, Madras which is a public place of worship.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been residing in the Matam premises, Elephant Gate, Madras which is a public place of worship.

facts.text: On March 22, 1963 at about 10 a.m. the appellant was arrested by the police.

anchor.surface_text: On March 22, 1963 at about 10 a.m. the appellant was arrested by the police and immediately produced before the VIII Presidency Magistrate on the same day

facts.text: The appellant was immediately produced before the VIII Presidency Magistrate on the same day on a charge under s. 4(1)(a) of the Madras Prohibition Act.

anchor.surface_text: On March 22, 1963 at about 10 a.m. the appellant was arrested by the police and immediately produced before the VIII Presidency Magistrate on the same day on a charge under s. 4  1   a  of the Madras Prohibition Act

facts.text: Allegation that the appellant was in possession of 3,960 grams of Ganja concealed in a wooden box in the Matam premises without any permit.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that he was in possession of 3,960 grams of Ganja companycealed in a wooden box in the Matam premises without any permit.

facts.text: The appellant pleaded guilty to the charge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded guilty to the charge and upon that plea he was companyvicted by the Magistrate to rigorous imprisonment for one year

facts.text: The Magistrate convicted the appellant to rigorous imprisonment for one year and a fine Rs. 50, in default to rigorous imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded guilty to the charge and upon that plea he was companyvicted by the Magistrate to rigorous imprisonment for one year and a fine Rs. 50, in default to rigorous imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: The appellant preferred Criminal Appeal No. 251 of 1963 to the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred Criminal Appeal No. 251 of 1963 to the High Court alleging that his eye-sight was very bad and defective,

facts.text: Appellant alleged bad eyesight, illiterate, knows only Hindi, no time to consult lawyer or disciples, proceedings rushed, did not really plead guilty, did not understand implications.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that his eye-sight was very bad and defective, that he was an illiterate person, number acquainted with English or Tamil or with any other South Indian language and that he only knew Hindi as it was spoken in Uttar Pradesh. He .also companyplained that he had numbertime to companysult either his lawyer or his disciples, that the proceedings were rushed through with undue haste, that he did number really plead guilty to the charge and that he never understood the implications of the offence or the proceedings before the Magistrate.

facts.text: The appellant filed an affidavit in support of the appeal before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an affidavit in support of the appeal before the High Court in regard to these allegations.

facts.text: Kailasam, J. called for a report from the VIII Presidency Magistrate regarding the allegations.

anchor.surface_text: Kailasam, J. called for a report from the VIII Presidency Magistrate with regard to the allegations made in the affidavit of the appellant.

facts.text: On April 23, 1963 the Magistrate submitted a report stating particulars explained in Hindi by Sri M. Sukumara Rao, Bench Clerk, plea interpreted, allegations false.

anchor.surface_text: On April 23, 1963 the Magistrate submitted a report as follows The particulars of the offence were explained to the accused by the Interpreter. It was translated to accused in Hindi by Sri M. Sukumara Rao, Bench Clerk of this Court who has passed examination in Hindi. The plea of guilty by the accused was also interpreted to the Court by Sri M. Sukumara Rao. The allegations companytained in the affidavit are false.

facts.text: Kailasam, J. confirmed the conviction and sentence and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Kailasam, J. companyfirmed the companyviction and sentence and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: This appeal to Supreme Court brought by certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. This appeal is brought by certificate granted under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution from a judgment of the Madras High Court

facts.text: Charge: On 22nd March 1963 at about 8 a.m. at No. 1 General Muthiah Mudali street in C-2 limits, the accused was found in possession of 3,960 grams of Ganja concealed in wooden box in his Matam premises without any permit.

anchor.surface_text: The charge reads as follows On 22nd March 1963 at about 8 a.m. at No. 1 General Muthiah Mudali street in C-2 limits, the accused was found in possession of 3,960 grams of Ganja companycealed in wooden box in his Matam premises without any permit. Hence the charge.

facts.text: Magistrate's judgment dated 22nd March 1963: Accused produced. Pleads guilty. Found guilty. Quantity huge 3,960 grams concealed in wooden box. Convicted and sentenced.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment by the Magistrate reads as follows Judgment, dated 22nd March 1964 -Accused produced. Pleads guilty. Found guilty. The quantity is very huge viz., 3,960 grams companycealed in a wooden box. I companyvict and sentence him to rigorous imprisonment for one year and to pay a fine of Rs. 50 in default 3 2 to rigorous imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: Supreme Court found violation of s. 243 CrPC as admission not recorded in words used by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest from the record that theadmission of the appellant has number been recorded as nearly as possible in the words used by him, as required by s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Requirements of s. 243 CrPC are mandatory, violation vitiates trial, conviction invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the requirements of s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code are mandatory in character and a violation of these provisions vitiates the trial and renders the companyviction legally invalid.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for possession of intoxicating drug like Ganja

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for possession of intoxicating drug like Ganja

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Madras Prohibition Act, 1937 Madras Act IO of 1937 as amended by Madras Act 8 of 1958 states 4. 1 Whoever- a imports, exports, transports or possesses liquor or any intoxicating drug shall be punished -- in any other case with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees, but in the absence of special and adequate reasons to the contrary to be mentioned in the judgment of the Court, such imprisonment shall not be less than three months and such fine shall not be less than five hundred rupees, in the case of the offence of import, export or transport of liquor or any intoxicating drug falling under clause a It shall be presumed until the contrary is shown- a that a person accused of any offence under clauses a to j of sub-section 1 has committed such offence in respect of any liquor or any intoxicating drug

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions on punishment and presumption for possession etc. of intoxicating drugs

concepts.interpretation: Requirements are mandatory; violation vitiates trial and renders conviction invalid; not empty formality but substance for fair justice and appeal rights.

anchor.surface_text: violation by the Magistrate of the requirements of s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code which states If the accused admits that he has committed the offence of which he is accused, his admission shall be recorded as nearly as possible in the words used by him and, if he shows no sufficient cause why he should not be convicted, the Magistrate may convict him accordingly.

concepts.unlisted_description: Recording of plea of guilty in accused's own words in summons cases

concepts.interpretation: No application where accused pleads guilty; s.243 special provision overrides this general provision.
s.243 CrPC (special for guilty plea) overrides s.362(2A) CrPC (general).
concepts.unlisted_description: Lex specialis derogat legi generali - special law prevails over general law

anchor.surface_text: It shall be presumed until the contrary is shown- a that a person accused of any offence under clauses a to j of sub-section 1 has committed such offence in respect of any liquor or any intoxicating drug or any still, utensil, implement or apparatus whatsoever for the tapping of toddy or the manufacture of. liquor or any intoxicating drug or any such materials as are ordinarily used in the tapping of toddy or the manufacture of liquor or any intoxicating drug or any materials which have undergone any process towards the manufacture of liquor or any intoxicating drug or from which any liquor or intoxicating drug has been manufactured, for the possession of which he is unable to account satisfactorily,

He .also companyplained that he had numbertime to companysult either his lawyer or his disciples, that the proceedings were rushed through with undue haste, that he did number really plead guilty to the charge and that he never understood the implications of the offence or the proceedings before the Magistrate. The appellant filed an affidavit in support of the appeal before the High Court in regard to these allegations.

arguments.claim: There was violation of s.243 CrPC as admission not recorded as nearly as possible in words used by appellant; record contains no indication of what exactly admitted.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed in the present case that there has been a violation by the Magistrate of the requirements of s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code which states If the accused admits that he has companymitted the offence of which he is accused, his admission shall be recorded as nearly as possible in the words used by him and, if he shows numbersufficient cause why he should number be companyvicted, the Magistrate may companyvict him accordingly. It is manifest from the record that theadmission of the appellant has number been recorded as nearly as possible in the words used by him, as required by s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Requirements of s.243 CrPC are mandatory; violation vitiates trial and renders conviction invalid; not empty formality but for proper justice and appeal rights.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the requirements of s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code are mandatory in character and a violation of these provisions vitiates the trial and renders the companyviction legally invalid. The requirement of the section is number a mere empty formalitybut is a matter of substance intended to secure proper administration of justice. It is important that the terms of the section are strictly companyplied with because the right of appeal of the accused depends upon the circumstance whether lie pleaded guilty or number and it is for this reason that the legislature requires that the exact words used by the accused in his plea of guilty should, as nearly as possible, be recorded in his own language in order to prevent any mistake or misapprehension. It his been held by the Madras High Court in Queen-Empress v. Erugadu 1 that the violation of the procedure in s. 243 of the Criminal Procedure Code was sufficiently serious to invalidate the companyviction of the accused. The same view has been taken by the Calcutta High Court in Shailabala Dasee v. Emperor 2 and by the Allahabad High Court in Mukandi Lai v. Stale 3 . In our opinion, these cases companyrectly lay down the law on the point.

arguments.claim: Under s.362(2A) CrPC, sufficient if Magistrate made memorandum of substance of examination of accused; not necessary to record actual words used by accused.

anchor.surface_text: It is submitted on behalf of the respondent that under s. 3 62  2   A , Criminal Procedure Code it was sufficient if the Magistrate made a memorandum of the substance of the exami- nation of the accused and that it was number necessary to record the actual words used by the accused.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.243 is special provision that takes precedence over general s.362(2A).

arguments.claim: s.243 CrPC is special provision that takes precedence and overrides general provision of s.362(2A) CrPC where accused pleads guilty.

Erugadu), Calcutta HC (Shailabala Dasee v. Emperor), Allahabad HC (Mukandi Lal v. State).
